docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Friday about companies that are cutting back health benefits for retirees or requiring them to pay more for coverage misstated the policy at AT&T. Employees outside union jurisdiction who began paying monthly premiums this year were those who retired after March 1, 1990, not those who were hired after that date.
docs.abstract: Correction of May 10 article about companies cutting back health benefits for retirees or requiring them to pay more for coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: A 26-day strike against Group Health Inc., the nonprofit health insurer, ended yesterday after workers ratified a new contract. The main issue was the union's refusal to accept the company's proposal for workers to start contributing money toward their health coverage.

headline.main: G.H.I. Employees Settle a Strike Over Wages and Health Benefits

docs.abstract: Strike against Group Health Inc, nonprofit health insurer, ends after workers ratify new contract; main issue was contributory health coverage; compromise settlement allows current employees to continue receiving coverage with no out-of-pocket expenses, but new employees will pay toward premium and co-payments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Frontier Ford, a nondescript dealership with a few rows of cars lined up in its lot in this small central Mississippi town, does not look like much of a competitive threat. ''I don't see how a little dealership in Carthage, where we have two red lights, can cause this much fuss,'' Butch Smith, the general manager, said while his salesmen leaned on cars, awaiting customers.

headline.main: Off the Reservation, Onto the Dealer's Lot

docs.abstract: Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, whose reservation is centered 25 miles east of Carthage, Miss, bought Frontier Ford, nondescript dealership with few rows of cars, earlier this year, provoking uproar among state's dealers; dealers worry that Choctaw tribe, because of its tax status, will undercut rivals on prices, even though it has promised not to do so; that tribe is considered adversary worthy of concern is evidence of its stunning turnaround; in 1970's, jobless rate among Choctaws was more than 50 percent, and college degrees were rare; unemployment has fallen to 4 percent, with ventures all over Mississippi; California tribe called Rumsey Band of Wintun Indians bought Ford dealership in Texas this year, but dealers there see that tribe as less of threat because out-of-state tribe cannot buy land and covert it into reservation territory; Mississippi Choctaws have promised attorney general that they will pay all sales and property taxes; dealers say tribe's promises can be broken; dealers want state's motor vehicle commission to rescind tribe's license to operate dealership and grant one that is conditional on tribe's waiving all tribal rights; one group dedicated to fighting economic incursion of tribes nationally--Coalition Against Sales and Excise Tax Evasion--consists of various trade groups; spokeswoman Holly Tuminello says tribes are very powerful and well-moneyed lobbying force; Mississippi Automobile Dealers' Association is leading push to curb tribe's tax advantages; Choctaw chief Phillip Martin is credited with raising tribe's fortunes by pushing Indian-owned enterprises; chart; map; photo (M)

keywords.value: COALITION AGAINST SALES AND EXCISE TAX EVASION

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study in Texas has concluded that patients are being improperly denied medical care by health maintenance organizations, particularly on initial claims for mental health treatment. The report by Consumers Union, which reviewed 263 appeals heard by the State Department of Insurance from March to September 2001, found that 70 percent of cases in which the H.M.O. rejected providing coverage related to mental illness were overturned when appealed to an independent reviewer. A spokeswoman for the Texas Association of Health Plans attributed the higher rate of overturned denials to the complexities of mental illness. Jim Yardley (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Study Questions H.M.O. Decisions

docs.abstract: New study in Texas by Consumers Union concludes patients are being improperly denied medical care by health maintenance organizations, particularly on initial claims for mental health treatment (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, said the federal government has subpoenaed documents about its relationship with TAP Pharmaceutical Products. The subpoena, which seeks information related to TAP's drugs Lupron and Prevacid, was received April 22 from the United States attorney's office in Boston, WellPoint said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

docs.lead_paragraph: A quiet rebellion by Republican backbenchers has forced House Republican leaders to reconsider and revise their plan to provide drug benefits to the elderly under Medicare. The dissent is being voiced by party members who find themselves caught in the middle of a fierce election-year battle among lobbyists for doctors, hospitals, nursing homes, health maintenance organizations, home care agencies and other health care providers fighting over a limited pot of Medicare money.

headline.main: Dissent in House G.O.P. Forces Leaders to Change Plan for Medicare Drug Benefit

docs.abstract: Quiet rebellion by Republican backbenchers forces House Republican leaders to reconsider and revise plan to provide drug benefits to elderly under Medicare; dissent is being voiced by party members who find themselves caught in middle of fierce election-year battle among lobbyists for health care providers fighting for limited amount of Medicare funds; Republicans complain plan would finance drug benefits in part by cutting Medicare payments to hospitals and other health care providers; ask Speaker J Dennis Hastert why they were being forced to vote against their local hospitals in election year; many object to plan because it also leaves big gap in drug coverage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Attorney's office in Boston has widened its five-year investigation into the sales practices of prescription-drug companies, subpoenaing records involving the distribution of a best-selling drug, Prevacid, made by TAP Pharmaceuticals. TAP, a joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries of Japan, and two managed care drug distributors, Caremark Rx and Express Scripts, said that they had received subpoenas in the last 10 days.

headline.main: Inquiry Into Drug-Sales Practices Is Widened

docs.abstract: US Attorney's office in Boston widens its five-year probe into sales practices of prescription-drug companies, subpoenaing records involving distribution of best-selling drug, Prevacid, made by TAP Pharmaceuticals, joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries, and managed care drug distributors Caremark Rx and Express Scripts; Caremark and Express Scripts say subpoenas requested records for Prevacid, ulcer treatment that had $3 billion in 2001 sales, as well as for Lupon, prostate cancer treatment, also made by TAP; three companies say federal investigators told them they are not targets of current phase of investigation;
docs.snippet: The United States Attorney's office in Boston has widened its five-year investigation into the sales practices of prescription-drug companies, subpoenaing records involving the distribution of a best-selling drug, Prevacid, made by TAP...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Financial Neglect of Mental Illness,'' [opinion, April 28] appropriately calls for support for mental health parity legislation at the state level. It should be noted that there is also legislation at the federal level to establish parity for insurance coverage of mental health services. It is the Mental Health Equitable Treatment Act, or H.R. 4066, and all of Long Island's Congressional delegation should co-sponsor this legislation and work for its passage. GLORIA S. ROTHENBERG Secretary DAVID FERRIN President Nassau County Psychological Association Merrick

headline.main: Call for Legislation On Mental Health Parity

docs.abstract: Nassau County Psychological Assn secretary Gloria S Rothenberg and president David Ferrin letter praises April 28 essay calling for support for mental health parity legislation at state level

docs.lead_paragraph: Columbia Hospital for Women, where more than 275,000 babies were born in 136 years, closed last Monday, unable to survive as a small, nonprofit medical center dedicated mainly to obstetrics and gynecology. With a mere 86 beds but a loyal clientele, drawn from the capital's political elite and its indigent and powerless, the hospital shut down because of a lack of cash that its managers and outside experts attributed to inadequate and tardy insurance payments.

headline.main: Cash-Poor Hospital for Women Closes Doors

docs.abstract: Columbia Hospital for Women in Washington, DC, where more than 275,000 babies were born in 136 years, closes; 86-bed facility is unable to survive as small, nonprofit medical center dedicated mainly to obstetrics and gynecology; health care experts say closing of small, specialized hospital is part of nationwide trend; some health care officials see private, specialized, nonprofit care that Columbia Hospital offered as obsolete approach; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a meeting of the Medical Society of New Jersey, but perhaps the planners did not include ear, nose and throat specialists. How else to account for the tin ear? Well, officials of the medical society insist it was a lack of available hotel rooms -- and not the state's skyrocketing medical malpractice insurance rates -- that drove them across the Delaware River to Philadelphia last weekend for their annual meeting this year.

headline.main: A Doctor in the House? No, They're in Philadelphia

docs.abstract: Medical Society of New Jersey spokesman John Shaffer says shortage of rooms and facilities at New Jersey hotels led to decision to hold annual meeting in Philadelphia (M)
